values:
Sis went to the States for a work trip but came back with tons of kitchen gadgets & goodies for me & clothes for Kailee!??!! :)  You go figure what work she was doing!

Anyway, thanks Sis for all the presents! *hugs*

Used the espresso powder she bought me to make Hazelnut Espresso Cookies. Although I'm no coffee drinker, the smell of the cookie was heavenly. Taste was not bad either. Note to self: have to remember to toast the hazelnuts 1st. Recipe taken from leitesculinaria.com/35177/recipes-hazelnut-espresso-cookies.html
                               

Also made Milk Chocolate Panna Cotta using a full cup of Nutella! Yummy! Very smooth & chocolatey. For once the gelatin did not play me out and set nicely. Phew! Recipe taken from The New York Times.
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/53515.html
Honeydew melon for mixing with rice cereal for Kailee's breakfast and chicken stew for her dinner. She likes honeydew but not the stew! Urrghhhh....
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/53424.html

Hubby signed up for the Aviva 70.3 which took place on Sunday 21st March at East Coast Park Singapore. The only way I could help him in his preparations was to carbo load him a week before race day.




Menu for the week:
1. Prawn chowder on potato mash
  
2. Beef red curry with lychees served with rice
  
3. Rösti topped fish pie
  
4. Home style fried rice
  
5. Sakura ebi linguine
  

Brought Kailee to watch her papa in a backpack/baby carrier thingy. She was ok throughout. No fussing around. Looks like it's time to hit the Bukit Timah walking trail! :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/53226.html

Kailee's got 2 new flavours on her menu this week - beefy broccoli and watermelon. Loves one but not the other.

Minced beef was fried in a non stick pan till no longer pink, then added to a pot of diced broccoli stems and leaves. This was cooked in beef stock for 20min till the broccoli was soft and then blended into a brownish green puree. Looks yucky, smells wonderful and tastes yummy. She loves it.

Since the weather's been so hot lately, I have a stash of watermelon in the fridge. Blended some to get watermelon juice, which I used in place of water to make rice cereal for Kailee. I'm surprised she doesn't like it too much since the cereal's nice and sweet. Humm, this confirms my observation that she likes savory food rather then sweet or sour!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/52828.html

Have grown a little tired of ang moh salads lately. Yearn for something with a little more punch & crunch. So it's Asian style salads that I turn to for a simple but satisfying lunch.

First up is an adaptation of Fish Leong's Thai Style Grilled Pork Salad. I marinaded the ribeye pork in hoisin sauce, shaoxing wine and white pepper for a 1/2 hour. Meanwhile, I cut the cucumber and bell pepper into pinky finger sized slices. Blended together fish sauce, lime juice, bird's eye chilli, garlic, chicken stock, sugar, coriander stem, leaves and roots for the dressing. Put the pork under the broiler and grilled for 10min till cooked. Sliced up cooked pork and arranged over cucumber and bell pepper pieces, poured over dressing, then garnished with mint leaves.

                                                                             

Next I tried an Asian Style Shredded Chicken Salad. Marinaded chicken breast with ginger juice, shaoxing wine, salt and sugar for at least an hour. Chicken was steamed for 10 min, left to cool, then shredded. Cucumber and carrot were cut into batons and shredded chicken placed atop. Dressing was made by boiling some chicken stock with oyster sauce, sugar, pepper and sesame oil. Finished salad with a sprinkling of thinly sliced spring onions and coriander leaves, and chopped toasted peanuts and sesame seeds.
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/52608.html

The smell of uncooked shrimp paste can be unappetizing to many. Shrimp paste is a common ingredient used in SE Asian cooking, with the different countries having their own variations of this condiment.

According to Wikipedia, shrimp paste is made from fermented ground shrimp, sun-dried then cut into fist sized blocks. It is not designed, nor customarily used for immediate consumption and has to be fully cooked prior to consumption since it is raw. It is an essential ingredient in many curries and sauces.

However upon cooking, this pungent smell mellows into the background, and becomes an afternote of seafoody goodness.

This dish - Steamed Shrimp Paste Pork is a classic example. It's simple to prepare but tasty to eat!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/52454.html

It's been so hot (34C) & humid lately that my brain's got addled. Don't know what possessed me to make a spicy hot soup for dinner!? Hubby & I were both dripping with perspiration when done. It's not that it wasn't good, it's just the wrong thing for this crazy weather!

Boiled some chicken stock with lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves & cilantro roots for 30min. Then added the shrimps, clams, sliced fresh mushrooms, red bell pepper & bird's eye chilli till everything was cooked. Poured this tasty broth over fresh kway teow noodles. Sprinkled chopped cilantro leaves over just before serving.
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/52013.html

To make amends for the cholesterol building & artery plugging meal on Monday, I made myself a healthy lunch of Tofu Cod Fishballs. Diced cod fish pieces were mashed up with drained japanese tofu & crunchy water chestnuts. The paste was then squeezed into balls after seasoning. Balls were steamed, then served with a piquant sauce comprising of garlic, shallots, ginger, spring onions, soy sauce, stock & chilli. The balls were garnished with ebiko & spring onions. So who said healthy food cannot be tasty?
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/51781.html
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/51558.html

Came across this recipe for sauteed chicken livers & mushrooms on toast & it immediately sparked a craving. Have not had such an old fashioned, home style dish in ages. Cooked it for lunch since hubby won't dig it.

It was YUM YUM YUM! Was so glad I made it but the thought of the cholesterol & fat levels make me cringe in guilt.  Aiya, once in a blue moon lah!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/51329.html

Lamb is my favorite meat, in all it's myriads of cuts & various cooking styles, across all cuisines. YUM!

Saw a packet of lamb shanks on sale in the supermarket so I quickly snagged it. Lamb is relatively expensive in Singapore so I grab it whenever I see it on offer.

Made Braised Lamb Shanks with Garlic-Herb Paste for dinner. I was captivated when I saw anchovy fillets as an ingredient. I love anchovy & it's unique taste which is best described as umami. Lamb & anchovies are a pair made in heaven! :)  Served it on potato mash & a pear spinach salad on the side. Hubby said twas good too! :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/50962.html

New concoction for Kailee - butternut squash with corn kernels. Boiled both squash & corn in some water till tender. Blasted them to smithereens in the blender. Put it through a sieve to get a silky smooth puree. Froze into individual portions for Kailee's meals. This one smells real good and is yummy yummy! Hope she likes it too...
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/50862.html

Hubby's pop idol when young was Sam Hui, who popularized Cantopop in the late 70s. Sam was in town for a concert & since hubby could not find anyone else who wanted to catch this act, I had to accompany him. I was praying that I wouldn't fall asleep! To my surprise the Singapore Indoor Stadium was almost packed to the brim & there were many die-hard fans. Sam, now in his 60s put up a spirited performance and kept up with his dancers. He belted song after song for close to 3 hours, with his 2 sons & brother appearing as guest stars. Not a bad way to spend Friday night!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/50609.html

We go back a loooong way, all the way back to 1985-86. We were young & innocent, fug-ly with thick glasses & hideous hair-dos, but much slimmer waistlines than now. We get along now just as well as we did then. Somehow the ties that we forged in high school are much thicker than those formed in tertiary education. It's a rare occasion that we get both Michelle & Wanqing back in town together so squeezed all our very tight schedules to meet for dinner. As usual we had a blast, with Guiying providing more 'classic' moments for us to cherish. To more of such good times!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/50224.html

PHEW! Survived our 1st Chinese New Year lugging Kailee (& all her barang barang) around! We had to deal with super hot humid weather, lack of air conditioning in houses filled to the brim with people, and tons of people jostling to carry Kailee and to take photos with her. Unfortunately my waistline did not do so well and my clothes are all pinching me! *sigh*

Our family had the usual round of extra activities - mahjong tournament, golf competition, poker & other card games & an outdoor physical activity. This year we tried our hand, or rather legs at Go Kart. It's fun but make sure you get the good car. Hell of a difference! :)

Here are some photos...
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/50022.html

Sis wanted to try our hand at making closed pineapple tarts just for fun. She roped me in and we got down to work last night. Gosh, it is so much easier then the traditional open faced type that we have been making! Just pinch a ball of dough, flatten it, wrap it around the premade ball of pineapple jam, then seal it shut! Like my friend's mother says, just 'bphut, bphut, bphut' and it's done! :)

                

This pastry is much softer & more flaky than the open face type, but the pineapple jam does not get baked directly. This means the jam does not get the nice chewy outer crust contrasting with the moist interior which some people like. To each his own taste!

So why call it Kailee's tarts? Cos we used her milk powder in the process! :)  This recipe called for 50gm of milk powder, which we did not want to buy since this was only a trial run. We improvised and used Kailee's Similac 2 instead! Very expensive milk powder!!!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/49919.html

Loaned my friend my kitchen for him to shoot his media campaign for Lam Soon. This meant that I had to halt my own CNY baking activities. Ahhh, back logged!

There was a lot of time, energy & sweat involved for just a short final, edited clip! An interesting day for Kailee as she grapples with all the unusual people & activity in out house. We not only got to sample all the yummy dishes but also got to keep all the ingredients used for the filming! :)

 
 
 Hawaiian Baked Brown Rice                                Stir Fried Seafood Spaghetti                                 Kalamata Olive Bread
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/49548.html

Made my signature CNY cake - 'Fa Cai' Prosperity Cake for my 2 next door neighbors.

These are 7" butter cake made in the chiffon style method where the egg whites are whisked separately then folded in. This method results in a lighter, less dense cake which I feel is more suitable for our warm climate & weather. In occasion with CNY, I added auspicious sounding or looking ingredients to the cake. Pistachios, dried apricots & fa cai were added. Pistachios kai (1) xin (1) guo (3) literally means 'happy fruit' in mandarin, fa (1)   cai (4) (a type of dried moss) is a tonal play on fa (1) cai (2) , which means strike wealth, and dried apricots look like gold nuggets. Just decorated it simply due to lack of time! :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/49155.html

Kailee's finished her all her pumpkin cubes so I made broccoli for her. Trimmed the broccoli florets into small pieces and peeled away the tough outer skin of the stems. Cooked the broccoli pieces in a little water, let it cool, then blended it. Put the blended mixture through a sieve then poured into an ice cube tray for freezing. A couple of houes later, & voila, Kailee's meals for the next week taken care of!  :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/49015.html

Kailee's done with her bout of constipation and my darling, happy, good-natured little girl is back! :)

We brought her to Chinatown to brave the noise & crowd last night. She was a real trouper. Not a whimper of protest. Just busy taking in the sights, smells & sound from her little perch on daddy's chest. It was so jam packed that I could not extricate the camera from my bag, so no photos of that adorable sight. Darn! But she was totally exhausted by the little excursion and crashed out in the car on the way home. 

I was happy to have managed to do some CNY shopping for both sets of parents. Now just one more trip to run before my hampers are complete!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/48811.html

I can hardly believe that CNY is just round the corner (next Sunday, to be exact)! Sis got me moving, and we decided to bake our regular CNY goodies, ie peanut-almond cookies & pineapple tarts this weekend.

Saturday was for peanut-almond cookie & Sunday pineapple tart. My personal fave is the peanut-almond cookie cos it packs a contrasting sweet-savory punch. Unfortunately for my waistline, I can pop a good 10 pieces of this cookie before my guilt laden brain makes me stop.

Saturday
8 recipes, 2l of oil, 2.8kg of flour, 2kg of icing sugar, much sweat & energy and a good 5 hours later, this was the fruits of our labor! :)

   

Sunday
8 pineapples, almost 4 recipes, 1kg butter, 2kg flour, 8 egg yolks, more sweat & energy, and 4 hours later, this was our spoils!

 
                                           

All these baking, plus Kailee's adventure with home made pumpkin and constipation (see previous 2 posts ) made this a hectic and  exhausting weekend! Can't believe I'm saying it but I can't wait for Monday & work to come!!!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/48465.html

It was the most traumatizing day for Kailee today since the day she popped out into this world. Read on only if you're not squeamish about the human waste disposal system...
 
I noticed that she was constipated yesterday and had spiked her milk with lactulose (a laxative). Unfortunately it didn't help and she was in distress as she tried to poo-poo. Her face was all red from the straining, her head & body soaked with perspiration, and she was wailing her lungs out. Left with little choice, I decided to 'shoot a bullet' up her arse! Meaning I stuck a suppository into her rectum. Thank goodness it worked and she managed to do her business 2 hours later. After some straining & more crying from her, she squeezed out 3 pinky sized little pieces of poop that's the texture of hard plasticine. Poor girl burst some blood vessels in the progress too. 

I am trying to determine if this is due to a change in milk powder (from Similac 1 to Similac 2), a changed from rice based cereal to a wheat based one or simply an increase in the amount of solids taken. Is either pumpkin or broccoli heaty? How can I make her drink more water without resorting to spiking it with fruit juices? Humm, questions questions questions...

I hope this successful 'clearing' means I get my happy, good-natured girl back, instead of the moody constipated one! Fingers crossed...
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/48314.html

Kailee was more receptive to the pumpkin today. *phew*  I defrosted a cube then watered it down, smashing the little lumps vigorously against the bowl. She ate it but didn't dig it like she had when I fed her those jarred ones. Humm, I wonder why? A little deflated but I'll think of more ideas to make it more palatable for her!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/48127.html

Since Kailee is taking in more solids per meal now, I thought I would start processing my own baby food for her. I have been testing her taste buds by gauging her reactions to different flavored jarred baby foods. She's a vege baby! Loves pumpkin & broccoli but dislikes fruits. I believe she doesn't like sourness, just like her mummy! 


Bought half a pumpkin from the market. Chopped it up and cooked it with a cup of water for about 25min till soft. Blasted it up in the blender and poured the mixture into an ice cube tray and froze it. Defrosted a cube at feeding time only for Kailee to reject my mashed pumpkin! Was so dejected! Discovered that it was still slightly fibrous. The picky little thing is used to super smooth foods. Urrgh.  Proceeded to strain the mixture through a sieve, then found that the mixture was now too thick. The poor girl could barely swallow. Had to thin the consistency down with hot water, but by then Kailee was totally disinterested in eating. *Urrgh* Will try again this afternoon. Have to persevere! Each jar of baby food costs $1.50 while my half a pumpkin was only about $1!!!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/47632.html

After a year & a half, I'm back! What's happened in the meantime?

I got preggers, puked my guts out, delivered a baby girl in 2 hours, went up a dress size (or 2!), opened & closed a milk production factory, took on concurrent jobs as maid, mummy & trader and aged like a decade!!!

Kailee just turned 7 months & we got a helper, which means that I finally get some free time for myself. I've been cooking up a storm to make up for lost time. I'll post some of the more interesting recipes when time permits. Photos are on my flickr site www.flickr.com/photos/junefoo/

Here's our baby girl! :D
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/47467.html

Went to catch Singfest 08 at Fort Canning Park on Sunday. T'was a fantastic lineup consisting of the crowd faves Jason Mraz, One Republic, Pussycat Dolls & Alicia Keys. Oh, the organizers even brought nostalgia back with Rick Astley! Rick had crazy women throwing bras & panties up at him!  :)  Tickets were really cheap at $200 for a full 9 hours of concert. Kudos to the organizers!

The weather was great. We brought our fully stuffed picnic baskets to munch & nibble in between the dancing. Wonderful day!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/47109.html

9 egg yolks were left over from the Swiss Meringue Buttercream for the cakes I baked over the weekend!!! What to do with them all? Sis suggested a quiche, so that's what I made for dinner! :)

Here's Gordon Ramsey's bacon, mushroom & rocket quiche, which I served with grilled asparagus with smoked salmon & shaved parmesan.
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/47037.html

The Singapore Dance Theatre marks their 20th anniversary this year with Ballet Under The Stars 08 at Fort Canning Park. This year's BUTS showcases the best of SDT's repertoire over the years.

We brought food & snacks & wine & had a picnic at Fort Canning. Was so inspired by the performance that we stayed back after the show to do some dancing ourselves! :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/46654.html

Went to catch Joey Chestnut & Takeru Kobayashi in action at the inaugural Major League Eating Asia 08. Oh boy they sure can eat. They are in a class of their own man! They each wolfed down about 5kg of chicken satay wheras the amateurs only managed about 1kg. D, sis' friend is the only female competitor who qualified for the finals. Go Des! Great job :)

To the delight of his hoard of screaming fans, Kobayashi edged out Joey to regain his title! Yeah!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/46476.html

A 10" carrot cake for Cowfu. Iced with cream cheese flavored buttercream & decorated with a pistachio border. Excess batter made into cupcakes for sis' colleagues.

                   

I just love carrot cake! Both the local Singaporean type as well as the ang moh version! :)

For lovely images of Singapore style carrot cake, click here http://flickr.com/photos/47075868@N00/2148805884 & http://flickr.com/photos/lastboltnut/2148799814/in/set-72157594364571706/
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/46307.html
Banana cupcakes with nutella centers, topped with a swirl of cream cheese buttercream & a chocolate transfer drawing.
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/46028.html

I went to admire the displays at the Singapore Garden Festival currently on at the Suntec Convention Centre. There are really some beautiful fantasy & garden landscapes on show. Very inspiring! Picked up a couple of ideas for my home.  :)  But my fave area has to be the Orchid Show on level 4. The variety & colors of orchids are simply amazing!

There are also bargains to be had at the Marketplace area. Basil & mint plants only $4.90/pot!

 
       

More information here http://www.singaporegardenfestival.com/
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/45818.html

Came back from Hong Kong with aching calves & sore gluts. Shopping's such a great workout! :)

Decided to try the latest fad in town - fish spa, to exfoliate all the calluses that formed over the weekend! These fishes are called garra rufa, same species as the 'doctor' fishes that clean sharks & mantas in the wild. They are supposed to feed on our dry & flaky dead skin.

It's a terribly uncomfortable sensation the first couple of minutes, & made worse when you see all the fishes swarming around you feet. The entire floor of the building could hear us screaming away! Very eeky! After you get used to the sensation though, it becomes enjoyable, especially around the calves area. Our feet & hands were indeed soft & smooth after the 30min session! :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/45373.html

I went with my group of best gal pals to Hong Kong over the weekend. We finally managed to arrange our schedules and find a time when all of us are able to pop over to HK for a weekend getaway. What with spending time as newly weds to becoming mummies to powering careers, we haven't been able to spend much quality time with each other without any distractions. We've known each other since we were young & innocent & hideous (pre contact lens era, bad hairdos, braces etc) 12 year olds! We go back a loooong way!

We had a blast in HK. Laughed tons, ate buckets & shopped till we dropped. Oh, & danced, & drank & flirted shamelessly too!!!  :)  It was really hilarious fun! It's uncanny how little we've changed. We clicked and got along just like when we were back in school. A little older & wiser perhaps, but still crazy!

Best shopping bargain: 6 pairs of Nine West shoes for S$320!!!
Best local eating spot: jing wei ju on 2 Peel Street (signature dish - roast lamb shan dong style)
Best night spot with live music: INSOMNIA
Favourite group photo:
 
Favourite 'fugly' photo:


It's been such a blast that we've vowed to make this a bi-yearly event. Can't wait for the next trip!  :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/45188.html

Had some relatives from the Big Apple in town. Took them out on a boat trip around the outlying Singapore islands. Fishing, swimming, pigging out.... Fortunately the weather held up and I managed to get a tan too!  :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/44884.html

Made this jelly to be served with cheeses. Had a slight problem with the pectin from Phoon Huat. Somehow the jelly was too soft, even after re-cooking it. Perhaps the concentration is different from those sold overseas. Gotta tweak the recipe. Taste was yum yum though...

                                 

Update: Used gelatin powder to firm up the jelly and it worked! Texture is perfect now.  :)  Hopefully the taste isn't compromised!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/44715.html

The red glutinous rice wine that mum & I made was finally harvested after 21 days. I find it to be slightly on the sour side. Does anyone know why?

     

The 1st dish that I made using our wine was drunken chicken. Chicken thighs were marinaded overnight with the rice wine, ginger, scallions, soy, pepper and sugar. The whole dish was then steamed for 40 minutes and kept in the fridge overnight before serving. The wine and chicken juices will harden into a flavorful jelly, otherwise known as aspic in culinary terms. Slice chicken just before serving together with the aspic. The flavor was not too bad but I think can do with more alcohol. But then I'm an alcoholic... :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/44065.html
Hubby's so proud of his tool board which we set up together in the storeroom over the weekend. Ain't it cool?! :)  Gosh, we are getting so domesticated!!!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/44329.html

Have been pigging out too much lately so I thought I'd make a vegetable curry dish for dinner. A mixture of cabbage, carrot, turnip & long beans were used, with the addition of quail eggs and tau kwa. Very yummy with plain white rice.

Yes, it was plenty of vegetables but it just struck me that the coconut milk's not that healthy. Will try to substitute the coconut milk with skim milk or yoghurt next time and update on that turnout.
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/43997.html

Bought this wooden cinnamon bowl from Bali for salads as it's sufficiently deep. It's also light and un-breakable, making it easy to pass around. The inner surface is lined with the pretty iridescent mother-of-pearl shell. Very pleased with this purchase.

                                            
Tried this recipe from Take Home Chef which called for coating a frenched rack of lamb with a breadcrumb mixture flavored with orange and rosemary. I thought it sounded interesting but the taste can be improved upon. Will work on it...Hands were too oily to take a decent photo after the carving. Sorry!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/43689.html

Singapore finally bid farewell to the National Stadium (a new sports hub will be built by 2013)...Hubby had a few glorious moments on the track in his younger days so he brought me there to savor the memories and snap some photos as keepsake. I felt a little sad as the grand old dame was looking rather shabby and desolate...
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/43409.html

Thanks to the boss of Boon Tong Kee who shared his company's recipe for a Singapore favourite - Hainanese Chicken Rice! :) 

According to him, the 'secret' in making the chicken oh-so-tender is to hold the chicken by it's neck and dunk it 5 times (in a up & down motion) in hot boiling water flavored with ginger and scallions. After that place the chicken breast down in the hot water, turn off the heat, cover the pot and let stand for 1 hour. Place chicken in an ice bath for a taut glistening skin. Chop into bite-size pieces for serving.

This is my attempt...Not too shabby! :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/43260.html

I bought the Canon Ixus850 IS for hubby's birthday last year (which I have been hogging!) and he bought me a Nikon D80 for mine this year! Yippee! Thanks dear! :)

We set up a photography showdown with each other on Sunday. Location was the Floral & Forest Walk sections of the Southern Ridges Walk (http://www.nparks.gov.sg/southernridges.html ). Yes, I know it's a terrible disadvantage for him to be using a point & shoot while I use a DSLR! Hehe... 

Sunday turned out to be cloudy, which wasn't perfect for a photography sesson but it made for an thoroughly enjoyable walk. A nice cool day with lovely views...what more can one ask for? :)

Here're some of the photos...

By hubby
    

By me
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/42803.html

Had to fill up some bare spots in my garden so went flower shopping at Far East Floral. Wow, just realized that even potted plants are getting expensive here in Singapore!

Bought 2 pots of Anthurium, 4 pots of Petunias and 2 pots of Cuphea and a pack of mosquito dunks. The bill came up to almost $100!

*sigh* Inflation's a killer!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/42470.html

Have been feeling slightly lazy to cook lately so bought a pack of tortilla wraps, striploin and an assortment of vegetables to make beef wraps.

Real easy dinner. Slice vegetables, grill steaks, spread on cream cheese, pile ingredients onto tortillas and voila, dinner! :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/42684.html

When mum asked me to join her for the above class, how could the alcoholic me say 'no'? This is a Modern Living course series by PA and taught by Gina Choong.  

We Hakkas use red rice wine lees in our cuisine a fair bit so I am keen to learn the process. Besides, it's alcohol. Need I say more? :)


                      
                      
                      
Wine can be harvested after 21 days... :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/42076.html

Hubby requested something fusion for dinner so I surfed the net and came up with this interesting recipe - Honey garlic green tea shrimps with macademia nuts. Sounds yummy? 

Well overall the taste was not bad but the green tea flavor wasn't distinct enough. Will tweak the recipe and see if I can improve on it... Served rei shabu (cold pork shabu shabu) as appetizer. I just adore food that allows me to eat with my bare hands!
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/41929.html

I love Bintan as a quick weekend getaway, especially if I'm in the mood to just chill and recharge my batteries.
                            
Went with hubby for the triathlon and stayed at Angsana instead of Nirwana Gardens cos we dilly-dallied and left it too late to make room reservations. 
    

Did the sun-kisser spa treatment to soothe my burnt back from the dive trip and horrors...tiny blisters broke out all over my back the next day! Fortunately it's less painful than it looks and my back just looks ugly from all the peeling.  :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/41644.html

Joined Red Scuba on their Kuantan Wreck Live-on-Board over the Vesak Day weekend. Spent 4 days 3 nights on MV Seabourne. Have to say hubby & I were pleasantly surprised by the quality of food served on board! :) Our tummies were well satisfied.

Dived at various Tioman sites on the way up to Kuantan but the highlight of the trip was definitely Kuantan Wreck. It's a Japanese oil cargo ship that was sunk in the mid 1970s. I was initially apprehensive about a wreck dive cos have been watching too many Hollywood movies where divers get lost in the eerie ship filled with dead bodies everywhere! Felt a little letdown when was told that there will not be any diving inside the wreck as sections of it have collasped already. The visibility was superb - almost 20m! Tons of fishes and marine life. Thoroughly enjoyed this site!

Perhaps it was due to the full moon, but the surf was rather bad. Quite a few divers didn't manage to get out of their rooms for the whole day! Fortunately both hubby & I are comfortable travelling over water. Not a bad way to spend a long weekend! :)
http://junefoocy.livejournal.com/41423.html

J who's with the Great Wheel Corporation, brought us on a complimentary tour of the Singapore Flyer, with VIP treatment and all! Thanks! :)

We went on the evening tour of 7pm which gave us both the daytime & nighttime views of Singapore's skyline. Fantastic! We had so much fun, the time flew by too quickly. 

Facts:
Highest wheel in the world (so far) at 165m
Time for 1 full revolution is 37min
Each cabin sits 28 people VERY comfortably
